151234009.review:
I don't really put reviews on games because I can never really know what I could say to make a convincing argument to make people play a game however, this is definitely one of those games that I've seen multiple times surprise people with enjoying! I knew from the moment I saw this game that I would enjoy the visuals at the very least and the concept behind it interested me greatly though I never expected me to be as addicted as I am!

I'm more of a casual game sort of person so roguelikes never crossed my mind into enjoying but with this being my first game of the genre, I'd say it's really good for a newbie and I'd say that friends I know who've explored the genre more have enjoyed the combat system as well (especially with the Relic of The Old Faith update). I can say the most entertaining part for myself and many of my friends is watching and helping your cult grow from the ground up. The progression of seeing everything just feels like watching an ant farm at work.

Alongside that, the music alone just make this game really pop. River Boy's music alongside the beautiful/adorable/horrifying visuals make this game SUPER worthwhile! I genuinely listen to the soundtrack interspersed with my many playlists as I work.

I would say there's a little bit of something for everyone with this one! Have recommended and will continue to recommend!

Very chill and cute despite the occult themes, Cult of the Lamb is 60% cult simulator and 40% roguelite action. 150875968.review:
Game is good, but a little on the tedious side.

If you play with a keyboard and mouse skip it. For some reason they designed the attack aiming when using kb+m to use both the wasd movement controls AND the mouse AT THE SAME TIME. So if you're running to the left and your mouse cursor is to the right of your character then the game will ignore your mouse input and attack in the opposite direction of what you want to happen.

This game has been out for a long time and this still hasn't been changed. It's such an obvious flaw anyone using a kb+m could tell you it's bad within 1 hour of playing the game.

If you want to play with a controller by all means give the game a shot. The story is not your typical hero save the world which is nice to see a change in pace for a while. The follower/cult building mechanic is pretty decent although with a few flaws of it's own that prevent it from being great.

150844989.review:
Cult of the Lamb ne révolutionne rien et propose une formule finalement assez simple. Mais il le fait avec cohérence, une direction artistique très réussie, un univers irrésistible et en soignant le moindre détail. Bref le résultat est quasi irréprochable.

On se retrouve donc avec deux phases de jeu :

- d'un côté un Zelda-like (dans l'esprit du Zelda de l'ère 8/16 bits s'entend, la roulade en plus et une maniabilité évidemment plus agréable), mâtiné de rogue-lite mais de manière quasi anecdotique. On affronte ennemis et boss et on collecte des ressources.

- de l'autre un petit jeu de gestion de sims - enfin de cultistes dans le cas présent : il s'agit de pourvoir à leurs besoins (matériels et spirituels) pour qu'ils génèrent en retour la foi qui va nous permettre de développer nos capacités de combat. Développer son culte est un vrai bonheur : qu'il s'agisse des bâtiments à construire, de leur préparer à manger ou de se perdre dans les nombreuses options cosmétiques et la personnalisation de ses fidèles.

Evidemment les deux phases de jeu se répondent, y compris sur un mode négatif car le temps est une ressource à partager entre ces deux aspects et multiplier les revers dans l'un aura des répercussions dans l'autre, principalement en raison du temps perdu en cas de morts répétées (les cultistes vieillissent et meurent et d'ici là il faut bien les nourrir).

Graphiquement le jeu est très mignon et il exploite à merveille cet aspect (de nature à dédramatiser) en poussant le contraste avec son univers, certes parodique, mais parfois assez malsain dans les options proposées.

En incarne ici stricto sensu l'agneau sacrificiel (le dernier de son espèce !) et on se retrouve sauvé et enrôlé par une déité captive pour fonder un culte et lui venir en aide en contrepartie.

Et s'il est un point que je n'ai volontairement pas évoqué plus haut c'est l'importance de nos cultistes en tant que ressource : d'une part parce qu'on peut les sacrifier directement pour en retirer divers bénéfices mais surtout parce qu'on va dessiner les contours moraux de notre culte tout au long du jeu via des décrets mutuellement exclusifs (un peu comme les doctrines d' un Civilization), avec des conséquences sur le style de jeu et sur sa tonalité.

Au final Cult of the Lamb est dangereusement addictif : des boucles de gameplay courtes (10-15 minutes) et des options de personnalisation qui créent un fort attachement à son culte et à ses membres. Le tout scellé dans un univers joyeusement déviant.

150512999.review:
Good game.

Satisfying loop of somewhat intense combat/dungeon crawling and cozy animal crossing-like community management (but with the ability for cultists to die/get sick/etc). You can go from zelda-like break all the pots for small collectibles to actually investing all the little collectibles in your community. 

It's not grindy and death is not very punishing, the game is always rewarding you for playing it. The roguelike elements happen within the game's story which also gives a definitive stopping point if you don't want to commit yourself to playing past the point of being sick of it. For me this was about 18 hours in.

Glitches are a bit troublesome and can make an awful first impression, but if you can, stick it out a dungeon or two. 

Art's great. Music and sound design's great. 

Just... if satanic gore isn't your thing you'll have difficulties with the game. Don't get it if you think Satan manipulates people through video games. Or do, your money'll just go to steam and them.

150389739.review:
I really want to like this game, but I just can't get into it. That's not to say this game is terrible, but there are big flaws.

Battles feel repetitive, and it doesn't feel as satisfying as some other rogue-likes, primarily Hades, to complete a full run. Runs feel either too hard or too easy, and there just isn't any in-between. Controls in this game feel too simple as well. There's an attack button, dodge, and that's it. Fights in this game consist of repeatedly mashing the attack button and dodging the occasional projectile or lunge forward. Enemies, with the exception of some bosses, feel too easy to beat. Collecting food during runs can also be tedious even on normal difficulty where you have to constantly be collecting it as your main priority for keeping your cult alive. The perks that you earn in the runs feel too simple and easy to get.

The other half of the gameplay, which is actually taking care of your cult is alright, albeit serviceable, but it doesn't feel deep as I want it to be. That might just be because I haven't played much of the game. But I don't enjoy a lot of this game which makes me sad because I really wanted to like this game.

Cult of the Lamb just doesn't know the kind of game it wants to be. It wants to be many things, yet succeeds at neither. If you're looking for a rich rogue-like inspired by Hades that has inticing gameplay, Cult of the Lamb isn't it, and the other side of the gameplay doesn't exactly deliver either. Sadly, I do not recommend this game. There are far better rogue-likes out there.

150273365.review:
I liked the take on the usual tech tree thing, having the devotion tree fill that role, but also having the fleece and doctrine skills. I enjoyed the combination of roguelike with building a base that has a little more room for individual variation, unlike something like Darkest Dungeon. The art style is cute, and there's something hilarious about the little lamb going into red-eyed murder mode

Despite the fact that I liked it enough to play for several hours, I really can't recommend it for the shallowness of the game compared to the price of the game. When I think of games like Graveyard Keeper, which I picked up for 20 bucks, this game fizzles out fast. Each of the other areas you can travel to feel very empty, with very few things one can actually do in those areas. Sure, I can pick up new skins for my cult followers, but if you don't care that much about that (and I don't) then there's little else to do. Fishing can yield several varieties of fish, none of which matter because the cooking recipes treat most of them as the same fish. Much of the game feels like this: substantive at first glance, but very superficial when you go to see what you can "do" with it.

The game is also buggy, or just has design moments that are frustrating. My followers returning from quests bugs out their dialogue with some regularity. The tutorial dialogues that pop up in new situations in new areas doesn't pause the gameplay underneath, so you stupidly think you can read what they're trying to teach you when really you're just getting martyred while you read.

Until Steam allows a neutral or star-based rating, I have to keep giving games a "thumbs down" that I would say might be worth picking up on serious discount or if you are not at all concerned about spending your discretionary income. But if you're at all having to balance game purchases for "good time for the money," I wouldn't say this one ended up being it, for me.

My main criticism of this game has to do with the difficulty scaling. The dungeons feel quite easy if you don't play on extra hard, but the cult management is brutal and requires specific doctrine decisions if you want to buy yourself the time to actually go on quests. Fortunately, since difficulty can be changed at any time and there are options you can use to make cult management easier if you're struggling, I don't think it's an issue that should stop anyone from enjoying the game.

It's a solid 9/10 that is still going to get more content updates and I highly recommend it.

150045312.review: Cult of the Lamb is a delightful twist on the cult genre, where managing an adorable cult becomes simultaneously funny and challenging. Picture this: fluffy cult leaders, sacrificial rituals with cute sheep, and an unholy dose of chaos. The game taps into the unexpected joy of herding sheep, turning it into a strategic, yet amusing experience. Forget traditional world domination – here, it's all about embracing your inner shepherd and navigating the whimsical world of fluffy followers. Cult of the Lamb takes the cult game concept to a whole new level, proving that the key to a successful cult is, unsurprisingly, a flock of fuzzy companions. It's a quirky, humorous journey where you might find yourself chanting "Baa-men" instead of the usual "Amen." So, if you've ever wondered what it's like to lead a cult with a woolly twist, this game is your ticket to an entertaining, sheep-filled adventure.

150044589.review:
A really charming and entertaining game. 

Cult of the Lamb is a mix between a City Builder and Rogue-Like, and it surprisingly does both sides pretty well, the combat side is fun and highly replayable, it can be challenging even at the lower difficulties, so caution is advised, the city building aspect is what you expect for the most part, you gain followers for your cult and you gotta make sure to meet their needs in order to keep them loyal and happy, which can be harder the larger it is, specially when it comes to keeping them well fed, you can customize your Cult with several buildings, which can help keeping it going or being simple decorations. 

As you go through the game, you unlock several things that can affect your run, one being the fleeces which will have a different effect on your Crusade, such as increasing magic dmg at the expense of HP and Melee dmg, or making you run faster and having more HP while being unable to roll.

The other thing is the Doctrines, every time you unlock one you get to choose between two of certain categories, this will affect how your Followers behave and react to things, such has making them accept Sacrifices rather than being afraid of it, or making them Cannibals lmao, later on in the game you get the ability to obtain the ones you missed, so feel free to go with what you wish. 

Overall the game is pretty good... sadly, theres one issue i couldnt ignore, bugs, yeah the game bugged for me on several occasions, for the most part it was visual bugs, so it didnt affect me much, but on other times it did cause me to have to reset the game to fix it, and it could be frequent at times, which did got annoying, despite this, the game is still fun and worth to play.

If it wasnt for the bugs i would give it something higher score. 

8/10, definitely worth.

150019452.review:
Cult of the Lamb was a surprise for me. Initially, I had no interest in playing this game, but my project teammates picked this game to deconstruct for an assignment. I already knew the strong visual presentation of this game, but the gameplay totally surprised me by being much better than I expected. The first few hours of the game were incredible, as I went through a mostly blind playthrough of the game. As much as I love the "two games in one" approach this game took, the magic kind of fell apart after that initial few hours.

Cult of the Lamb's job is already hard from the get-go, being both a dungeon crawler and base builder. If you have ever designed a game, you might have a clue how hard it is to develop and balance a few systems alone, yet this game has two separate big gameplay parts, with a good amount of systems in itself. My enjoyment of the first few hours of the game comes from this aspect of the game, both systems are equally important and they are so interconnected that you never feel like you are playing two games at once. Of course, maintaining this is hard and the connected nature of the game dissipates after those initial hours, making the difference of gameplay portions much sharper than it should be. Still, both gameplay portions never became boring altogether as they are well-designed on their own. Dungeon-crawler part always introduces new enemies, and as you master the game’s controls your enjoyment of this portion of the game nearly matches that first few hours. I sadly cannot say the same for the base-building part, as it is very easy to master, and it gets more and more boring as you progress through the game. The balance of the time you spend on each portion also changes, as the game wants you to spend more time on the dungeon crawling part. Still, even with all the problems, I really enjoyed what the gameplay offered. Never in my playthrough, I got the urge to abandon the game, and for a guy like me who often struggles to finish playthroughs and this game being a 14+ hour game, that is an achievement altogether.

The presentation may be the strongest part of this game, especially for an indie game. If you have seen any promotional material, you already have a grasp of the strong art style of the game. But I never expected the sounds and the soundtrack to be this good. I was genuinely shocked when the music started to play. The soundtrack mostly consists of bangers, and the variation is immense. Sound design is also very strong, as you can get a lot of information on gameplay from just listening to sounds. Visuals are also designed to be in the same manner, but the focus on presentation sometimes clashes with that philosophy. For example, sometimes the game puts you in small rooms with a ton of enemies that shoot projectiles, cluttering your screen and making it very hard to dodge enemy attacks, thus hindering the flow of the gameplay. All-in-all, I was left impressed with the presentation of the game, even though the game could have done a better job with visibility.

That’s everything I wanted to talk about, I guess. There is also a narrative portion of the game, but I never became curious enough about it to analyse it and form an opinion. I feel like a sequel could fix all the problems I have with this game and expand it in a multitude of ways as there is a lot of potential to do so. I’m glad my teammates have picked this game; I do not think I would have ever played it otherwise. I am giving it a solid 8.5/10, as I start my wait for a potential sequel that I think is a given at this point.

I think a lot in this game is done right.
Mixing management with an Isaac-like Roguelike Combat Formula works quite well.
Its a good contrast. Despite a lot of peoples opinion that the management aspect is tedious, I find it quite simple and relaxing. 

Combat wise the game lacks some level of depth tho. Most of the cards are just clutter and some things are just not worth upgrading at all. While the types of melee weapons play a little bit differently, all feel very similar in a way, because they basically just differ in their attack speed. They have different move sets, but when you try to avoid getting hit, its more like hit and run for every type of weapon and it doesnt really matter which one you get. Secondary Upgrades like Poison, Vampiric, Necrotic attacks doesnt really add up in a way that it alters the gameplay greatly. 

Art wise the game is gorgeous but it has some problems with "design follows function". The point of view in the game with a very small character makes the game hard to play on small screens like the Steam Deck. While the art design in combination with the diagonal point of view is very nice to look at, it would most certainly play better in a more traditional point of view. Getting hit by stuff you just didnt see properly happens a lot of time.

8/10

--------------------------------
[h3]TLDR Review - Detailed review below[/h3]
[b]Pros:[/b]
- Very cute art style and art in general
- Fluid gameplay and combat
- I'm so attached to my cult I don't ever want to sacrifice them :( 
- Story is simple, main focus is base building and rouge-like dungeon combat
- Soundtrack is so catchy
[b]Cons:[/b]
- Game too short, some grindy parts can be cheesed through quick
- Unbalanced difficulty; it can be too easy at times and too difficult at others
- Game makes you feel like your choices do matter in the long run, and I suppose to a certain extend that is true, but for the most part I don't even think it would matter too much unless you're going to mega minmax the shit out of the game

--------------------------------
[b]NO SPOILERS HERE![/b] Some things to note about my playthrough, take into account I played at the recommended difficulty:

[b]EARLY GAME[/b]
- Early game base building was never too difficult as I've never struggled to keep my cult alive and well throughout my run. Difficulty usually stemmed from combat
- The "Faith" bar was NEVER an issue for me throughout my playthrough so it's purpose was somewhat useless since I could always counter low faith with sermons and inspire 
- Early game combat was quite rough, having to die a lot before getting a good footing in the combat. I enjoyed the combat, it's very fluid and the game feels awesome. However, I've seen comments about how the combat isn't to everyone's liking and I can completely see that. Much like any rouge-like, I'd say the random weapon you get at the start of every crusade will make and break your run, so use RNG to your favour when you get lucky. 

[b]MID GAME[/b]
- Early to Mid game grinding for resources is quite rough. I'm constantly running out of stone and wood. I tried all I could to grind, making those resource generation buildings and going on crusades but it never is enough. At some point to the Mid-Late game resources are in abundance so you won't have to care about it anymore.
- Combat starts getting a lot easier after leveling up and I ended up breezing through crusades, rarely dying.
- Prayers are generating at a steady rate and this is where I can see the game steam rolling through difficulty soon

[b]LATE GAME[/b]
- By late game, I've stacked up so many followers and I don't even feel an issue keeping all of them alive. The farming in this game basically sets you up for your followers to never die (exception old age)
- I've maxed out my cult upgrades and combat upgrades by early late game and at some point the praying mechanic becomes quite useless. I feel like I've progressed the cult upgrades too quickly just by having so many followers, and having no penalty in doing so.
- Towards the end of the story (around the last crusade world and final boss), combat starts getting a lot harder as I've maxed out all my upgrades and now it is up to RNG and skill to finish the story. This part here is where I struggled the most (maybe because I suck) but with patience and practice I beat the final boss in about 4-5 tries.
--------------------------------
[b]Last thoughts:[/b] 
I love this game so much and I am so sad that it is so short. I originally bought it for the art style but I stayed for the gameplay. I highly recommend Cult of the Lamb to anyone who likes Rouge-Likes or micro managing base creation. While the whole base building aspect is too easy at times, I still enjoyed it. It doesn't complicate information and you never really find yourself lost or unsure what to do. I will probably come back and finish up some achievements or start a new run in the future :)

Having 100%'ed the game, I can say that I enjoyed it and it was fun while it lasted.

The game has two core parts to it, the base building and the combat.

The base building while deep, is primarily decorative. Once you build one or maximum two of most buildings you won't really need more of them with the except of the beds for the cult members. If you have a touch of the 'tism you could really sink into getting things just right for yourself. But I just bored with it after a bit and built what I functionally needed and got on with it.

The combat is really how you drive the game forward, and while there is a fair amount of depth. There are issues with the weapons and power balances. Some weapons, like the hammers are really slow and throw the pace of combat off and some of the fervor powers are quite weak.

Having said that, the game was still fun. It was quick and easy to engage with and the game play loop was quick and satisfying. I enjoyed it while it lasted.

149663057.review:
I left my PC on all night so remove about 12 hours of play from what it says.

Synopsis: You are a lamb that is sentenced to death by the Bishops of the old religion to prevent a prophecy from happening. Upon your death you are sent to the underworld where the "One who is waiting" (devil) grants you life if you agree to start a cult for him so that he can break the "Bishops" chains and be free again.

At first I didn't know what to think. The videos and images don't really give you a good feel for the experience. I saw "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews, but that has happened with other games I had seen and didn't like.
So here it is in a nutshell:
This is like a single player RPG base-builder. 
First, I will compare this to other games I have played:
Don't starve - It looks and feels like Don't Starve. I am only so far in the game but the main differences here are that you get followers to forage for you and it doesn't seem to be open world which brings me to my second comparison.
Guild of Dungeoneering - It is similar to this game in that you go through a dungeon of rooms with different pathways that contain different experiences: Battles, Merchants Farms etc. You walk through these to collect items and resources and get closer to defeating the "Bishops" (bosses).

The experience is that of you fighting your way through dungeons collecting resources building up your village finding followers and having them perform tasks like praying so that you can advance in the tech tree and unlock other buildings and powers. The game auto-saves and seems re-playable. I would recommend trying this game out as you will know within the first 60 minutes if you like it or not. 

On PC its the tab key to open inventory.

I recently got done with Relics of the Old Faith, and I gotta say, this game was a pretty fun ride, from base through the DLC.

I like how the base game has you focus a lot on creating, upgrading, maintaining, and expanding your cult, all while exploring different areas. It's a nice rogue-lite/ community maintenance game. Relics of the Old Faith, on the other hand, feels like a whole different dynamic. By this point, your cult is fully upgraded, and you likely have most of the fleeces and relics unlocked. Gameplay and story dynamic aside, this game was a lot of fun with the art style, gameplay dynamics with the different equipment and abilities you have with you in a run, plus a cute but sinister theme to it.
9/10, great stuff.

149502111.review:
1.) In the beginning, you have a limited number of attacks (3) to pass each dungeon phase. After those 3 attacks, you'll be empty and have to let the enemy kill you. If you clear a phase, your attacks do not reset, like in an old fashioned dungeon. If you kill enemies you can "recharge" your attacks as they drop "fervor", but clearing an entire phase and collecting this "fervor" only adds 1 additional attack. 

2.) The map and the freedom to move around it is locked until middle/late game. So, for most of the start you're attempting to pass dungeons which is tedious as you keep running out of attacks, waiting to die, respawning. There is no easy way to gain more attacks in order to pass more dungeon levels, like through side quests, so the pace of progression is limited.

3.) Finishing the entire game looks to take 300/350 hours, which is a large time investment for a game of this nature IMO.

It's a different kind of dungeon and fun to play especially due to the unique art and soundtrack, but it is repetitive and slow to progress. Personally, I cannot imagine repeating the same formula for 300ish hours just to reach "end game". The farming and cult management aspects do nothing to distract me from the monotony of the dungeons. This game might be a cult favorite but I'm a dissenter. Sorry.

149463810.review:
I can't say the game isn't good because it is pretty fun starting off, it has a really nice art style and soundtrack. and the combat feels mostly solid but the game starts to feel more and more like a chore as time goes on

You have to constantly babysit your cultists otherwise they will either die from sickness because they refuse to clean up after themselves when I have 2 cleaning stations or be useless because you have to interact with them individually to do anything with them, the colony management is overall too simple to its own detriment

And then there's the usual problems that come from roguelites with their randomness, which is also my main problem with the combat, The items you get while doing crusades feels completely rigged against you once you start unlocking new stuff, The Dagger and Sword are by far the best weapons in the game but good luck ever getting them because you will get nothing but the Claws, that require you to do a 3 hit combat to get decent damage with them since the first 2 hits are purposefully weak, which are out-classed by every other weapon, even the Axe and Hammer, which are at least consistent with their damage output even if they are stupidly slow to attack

And I've unlocked a lot of different cards (They give you buffs during crusades) but I haven't seen even half of them because I rarely get anything other than the starting cards

Also, Your attack direction is influenced by both your mouse direction and WASD, which led to so many times where I would attack and even roll in the wrong direction because I pressed a movement key a little too early or moved my mouse at the wrong time

I was really hoping I would like this game more because it didn't seem like the "Hope for the least bad outcome" type of game at first but that sadly isn't the case once you get further in

149461996.review:
Cult of the Lamb nailed the aesthetic of having a cult: On the outside, it is friendly and caring, and your leader gives you food, protection, and a place to sleep, but on the inside, the cult is dark and corrupt, and the same leader, you though is a friend or a father figure, can sacrifice you no matter how loyal you are. 
The whole game art style is cute-looking, but with a dark undertone, it´s beautiful. 
Music also helps create this atmosphere of calmness and harmony, but when the action starts, it can drop some great beats.
Combat is swift and precise. Thanks to the DLC, the combat is even more harder and has many things to complete and gather, like bishops as your followers.
The only complaint I have is the end game with your followers and buildings. There needs to be more stuff to build and upgrade because there is nothing much you can do after you build everything available. The same thing is with your followers as there is nothing much to do with them, mostly used for prayers and farming.
Other complaints are sometimes the game crashes during rituals, and sometimes the game lags when a lot of things happen at the same time, but it is not game-breaking stuff.
All in all the game is just terrific. 
Go, become a great leader, and destroy all the unworthy heretics!

I mean, it isn't terrible, just not good enough. I guess Hades destroyed the whole genre for me.

To be more specific, there's no strategy. All items are random, and they keep getting more and more random as you add new items to the list, for there is not a single way to direct, even by a little bit, the possibilities presented to you. Just roll with it. 

And the building part is far to simple to be of any interest. There are way more decorations than useful buildings, which is way too uninspired, in my opinion. Kinda "just throw a lot of options and people won't even notice they're useless".

I find myself close to the end of the main story, and yet it feels more like a chore than fun to keep on playing. Which is quite sad, since the game had a lot of potential. The idea of mixing two diferent styles is good, albeit risky. The art fits well with the theme, making it light instead of dreadful. It really makes me want to enjoy the game.

But I can't. It just doesn't feel fun. Go play Hades instead. I know i will.

149444881.review:
Getting 100% was... enjoyable in this cutely disturbing cult simulator.

approximate amount of time to 100%: 20-40
Estimated achievement difficulty: 4/10
Minimum number of playthroughs needed: One + DLC (a sort of NG+)
Multiplayer achievements: No.
Missable achievements: Yes. A single super easy one. (play dice with Rattau and win once you can and you can continue easily)
Grinding Achievements: No.
DLC-Only achievements: No. (but new achievements were added with updates)
Time-gated achievements: No.
Speed-run achievements: No.
RNG-achievements: A few. (some collectibles can spawn in rooms at random)
Does difficulty affect achievements: No. You can get 100% on easy.
First achievement unlock: Almost immediately at the start of the game. (sign the contract/Recruit a cultist)

Notes: 
- The game features negative achievements (like dying, sacrificing followers) achievements depend on these.
- The last 10~ hours were spent grinding the final item from cards/follower skins/relics etc..
- QOL Mods don't block achievements (like lock weapons or auto gather from chests...)
   (somewhat spoilery)
- the npc that sells "the Intangible" card is only found ONLY in Anchordeep [ The guides lie, he doesn't spawn everywhere ] - My advice is to keep 200~gold on hand and always buy all the card unlocks that are offered in random dungeon events.
- Make sure to chose the "resurrection" dogma.  With the free update you can select the dogmas you missed but that's very late into the game.

Overall the game was fun, It kept things varied between combat and base building just enough to prevent either from becoming stale. I personally love the art style and the only thing I found lacking were quality of life features (some of which can be easily modded in)

Overall this gets a strong recommendation from me. Go do unspeakable things to your followers

149444293.review:
COTL is a village-building game with roguelike elements to it NOT the other way around.
I'm a huge fan of roguelikes and when I saw this I thought I would like it. The problem here is that the roguelike aspect of the game is bad. You dodge, attack and repeat : that's the game loop of the game which doesn't feel rewarding at all.
The village-building aspect of the game is pretty good however but it just wasn't the part I was looking forward to.

The other problem is that the village-building and roguelike parts of the game are linked, as in you can't spend your life adventuring or building but are forced to do both. This means that if you are a fan of roguelikes but not so much of village-building or vice versa, the game forces you to play a radically different game to get back to the one you like.

Overall, pick the game up if you like village-building games and a little bit of roguelike (don't expect much from that thought) but stay away from it if you're only here for the action roguelike elements.

149264174.review:
[b]Cult of the Lamb[/b] es un título que prometía una experiencia única en el género roguelike con una narrativa encantadora y una jugabilidad adictiva. Aunque el mismo cumple con muchas de estas promesas, lamentablemente, también tiene un aspecto flojo, sus dungeons.

Desde el vamos, el juego se destaca por su pixel art de gran calidad y su mundo oscuro. La historia sigue a un cordero que, tras sobrevivir a un ritual, se convierte en el líder de su propia secta. Los personajes y las criaturas que vamos encontrando son únicos y llenos de carácter, lo que hace a la narrativa atractiva y emocionante.

La jugabilidad es una mezcla de elementos roguelike y construcción de bases, convirtiéndose en un título fresco. Tu tarea es la de construir y gestionar tu propia base, al tiempo que exploras dungeons y enfrentas peligros. La progresión es gratificante, ya que puedes mejorar y personalizar tu santuario y a tus seguidores. La combinación de elementos de roguelike, como la generación aleatoria de niveles y el combate desafiante, crea una experiencia adictiva que mantendrá a los jugadores comprometidos durante horas.

Sin embargo, donde [b]Cult of the Lamb[/b] tropieza son como anteriormente dije, sus dungeons. A pesar de su encanto, estas áreas carecen de la misma variedad y profundidad que el resto del juego. La generación de niveles puede sentirse repetitiva después de un tiempo, lo que limita la sensación de descubrimiento que se encuentra en otras partes del juego. Además debo sumar que algunos encuentros y enemigos pueden resultar injustamente desafiantes, lo que puede llevar a frustraciones innecesarias.

En resumen, es un juego que brilla en muchos aspectos. Su narrativa única, arte encantador y jugabilidad adictiva hacen que sea una experiencia que vale la pena jugar. Sin embargo, las dungeons, que son una parte fundamental de la mecánica del juego, no alcanzan el mismo nivel de calidad que el resto del título. A pesar de este "defecto", sigue siendo un juego que los amantes de los roguelikes y la construcción de bases deberían experimentar, pero con la esperanza de que en futuras actualizaciones puedan abordar sus "deficiencias" en este aspecto.

149137743.review:
In short: Yes, it's a good game, but the trailers do an AWFUL job at showing it. Don't let the art style fool you; trust me, it is still worth playing even if you hate it. I used to stay away from it because of the cutesy style, but then a friend convinced me to get it. When you see the environments and main bosses, they are actually REALLY beautiful. And the gameplay is REALLY fun. I highly recommend at least trying it.

Now for the long part: 

The gameplay is simple but effective. It is really fun. And the soundtrack is gorgeous. I'm not sure why this game doesn't have the roguelike or dungeon crawler tags because base building only takes up part of the game (especially if you don't care about base building like me lmao). It's mostly roguelike / dungeon crawling (called Crusades), which, in my opinion, is the best part about it.

If you're looking for lore / story, there's not much in here. It's solely focused on gameplay, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Again, the gameplay is super fun. It's just that there isn't much dialogue or lore to be read, which is fine. The small bit of lore it DOES have is pretty awesome. I just wish it had more for me to read about this universe.

HOWEVER, sad to say, what could've made this game much better is more variety; something it REALLY lacks in. And the game is REALLY easy. I had a feeling that it was going to be easy, so I played it in Hard mode, and still I beat the base game in only 3 days. For $25, I think that is a bit expensive for what little is in it, and I'm glad I got it on sale.

I hear they are still updating this game, so hopefully, they'll add more major bosses and stages. But otherwise, there's no reason for me to keep playing after I beat the base game and maxed out almost everything.

If you think you're a veteran / expert gamer in roguelikes, consider playing on the highest difficulty instead of just hard. Otherwise, you may just breeze through the game too quickly like I did.

In conclusion, it's a good game with a couple issues. Because of said issues, the game is an 8/10 in my eyes, maybe a strong 7/10. Good, but nowhere near perfect. But who knows, the problems may be fixed in future updates.

149023599.review:
After getting 100% of the achievements I can safely say - This game is dog water. 

I enjoy the art style, The game was entertaining for about 5 hours.  After that everything felt stale. Managing the cult isn't really interesting and is more of a chore than anything. 

The combat feels pretty bland, all of the weapons feel just about the same with slightly different swing speeds. 

The curses you get are either a knock-back + damage, a straight line, or a cone. The only worthwhile added effects behind ghosts or ice. 

The relics are boring. The only ones I can seemingly remember are the dice that give a 50/50 at health/invincibility. 

The non-major bosses are essentially all the same. Bullet-hell-lite spam with adds spawned in. Not super difficult, just tedious. 

[spoiler]The purgatory mode is an absolute joke. My god that last achievement was just so tedious. Time gating entering purgatory behind new days felt absolutely worthless. They succeeded in having me hold Y for a few minutes at a time.[/spoiler]

If you're looking for a time-killer that includes doing the same thing without much variation, then this game is for you. Otherwise, i'd recommend picking up a game that either focuses on being a rogue-lite/like, or a game that focuses on base building.

Ah yes, simulador de testigo. Yes.

Bromas y ofensas aparte. Seamos sinceros el juego es un pseudo animal crossing, stardwey valley y un roguelite.

No es malo. Es raro. Pero es curioso. Si quieres sentirte como David Koresh, creo que este juego lo pùede emular muy bien.

Jugabilidad, se hace entretenido, cuidar de tus creyentes mejorar tu campamento... Sin más, se hace agradable. Ahora el combate... Bueno, podria estar mejor. Obviamente esto no es un enter the gungeon, tampoco un Hades. Pero se defiende bastante bien, se hace un poco pesado a veces, pero no esta mal. 

En lo que historia respecta, no es mucha pero, esta ahi pero no le vas a dar mucha importancia porque vas a estar ocupado en que tus adeptos no se caguen encima.

La adición de twitch para que las personas lo puedan personalizar es un bonito detalle.

Ahora la banda sonora es muy buena, desde momentos de calma melodías pegadizas y difíciles de sacar de la cabeza (Ayuda me están abduciendo). De canciones que hacen que el combate sea más intenso y dinámico. Yo diría que le llega casi a la par de la banda sonora de Hades. 

Lo recomendaria? Pues, no te voy a mentir. Compra el juego, si no el cordero no me dará de comer. COMPRALO COMPRALO COMPRALO.

148556741.review:
I'm used to games like Risk of rain 2, Enter the Gungeon, deadcells, etc. Those games have transformative items that change a run entirely. This one doesn't even have different weapons. They're all the same, just with different damage and attack speeds. It really ruins the game's replayability, with the only different weapon being the hammer. It's cadence is different enough to justify being a different weapon.

The curses, essentially spells, aren't viable without a specific set-up. They don't have much variance either, being linear skillshots or hit-all-enemies automatically. It's not exciting. You can't control which ones you get either, making the more engaging spells even less accessible. It's a real shame since they have a lot of potential, yet aren't really utilized throughout the experience.

Another problem are the relics. You can't choose which ones you get, they aren't reliably attained, and they're not interesting. Once again, we're talking about a system that doesn't reward your investment, time, etc. It just wastes it. That's the problem with this game in general. 70% of this game is a flashy Idle clicker without any real interaction. Personally, that style of game doesn't mesh well with a rogue-lite at all.

A roguelite usually revolves around high interaction gameplay, is usually difficult, and it has high levels of variance from the itemization/random generation. In this situation, the items are incredibly boring, with the most impactful one I recieved in my entire run just increasing my attack speed by 50%. All of the rooms are small, and have little environmental variance, geometry, etc.

Really, this game is designed to not be a game while making you feel like you're playing one. It's kind of ingenious. The style, art, and music are all excellent, but it's all wrapping paper around a nothing burger of a game. So, while I wanted to like this game, it lacked all substance.

148511490.review:
[i] Cult of the Lamb [/i] is one of those rare games with religious themes. Given the complex nature of religious aesthetics, this game has no doubt nailed what it promised to deliver: the hypocrisy, the fanaticism, the blasphemous practices associated with cults, all of it. However, when it comes to its gameplay, I couldn't help but notice that the developers did not invest as much efforts as they did on aesthetics; it's repetitive and out of balance.

It felt as though the developers had a plan to flesh out its gameplay but halted it in the middle; the game still has a great potential for more gameplay elements, but they are simply not implemented yet. This was a bit sad for me because the developers did everything they could to deliver the aesthetics, writing, and worldbuilding, for all of which I had zero complaint and full scale satisfaction. Only if the gameplay was fleshed out, the game would have a phenomenal climax, but in its current state, I can't help but say the game feels rather anti-climactic. and labor-intensive.

That being said, I still do recommend this game for general audience, because it perfectly captures the gut-wrenching creepiness of cults in its art. You can also get a rough idea on how hundreds and thousands of people could go insane and do insane things just by playing this game. If you ever found yourself clueless on newspaper articles about some cults doing crazy stuffs just like I did, I believe you would have a quite enlightening experience playing this game.

148408743.review:
...I'm torn on this one. I like the dungeon delving a lot. It's got a snappy, sword-and-spell combat system with just enough delay so you know it's inspired by "Dark Souls" at least a little bit. You fight your way up to harder and harder bosses, and the combat keeps evolving. In between runs, you come back to your little cult and manage your flock. And it's silly and light and fun--you have to manage their beds, their food, their messes. Early on, when your cultists number small enough that you can count them on your hands, they feel like your chosen few.

But after maybe a dozen in-game days, the wheels just kinda fall off. :/ The dungeons start to feel repetitive, and the whole time you're being sent messages about how your cult is falling apart without you. As the cult gets bigger and bigger, your followers feel less like individual creatures and more like another resource you have to juggle. I've spent entire in-game days putting up beds, inspiring followers, rebuilding resource generators, giving sermons--bored out of my skull because I just want to go on another dungeon run. And that's not even getting into the tacked-on fishing minigame, the not-that-deep Knucklebones dice game, and the other two regions which are even less interesting...

It feels like the two halves of the game should play nice together, but they kinda... don't. In the end, I think it was only fun for Twitch streamers, who could laugh as the follower named after one of their subscribers begged to eat poop or sacrifice another subscriber.

148228274.review:
Not a bad game by any means, but didn't have that special something that made me want to play it more than all of the other games, movies, books, etc., that are already in my library. My problem is that the combat felt like something I've played many times before, a little bit of Bastion, a little bit of Hades, a little bit of 2D Dark Souls... all blended with Binding of Isaac but cuter visuals. You're rolling through attacks, punishing during openings, using the occasional special ability. This style of combat is really getting tapped out creatively. It's in the same place as WW2 shooters in the mid 2000s.

As for the base building and follower management, it felt so much like a free-to-play phone game that I was instinctively turned off. There are very few real decisions in the first hour, and when you can do something, you are railroaded through that single available choice. And the devs also made the weird decision to try and "spice up" otherwise boring tasks by including silly little reflex tests. Example: cooking berries from a recipe is boring, so they make you click "cook" while a slider is moving back and forth. I found this annoying rather than amusing, sine it just meant spending more time on the cooking screen.

The game has its upsides. Story is interesting, as are the characters you meet on your journey. But the two core gameplay segments just did not do it for me.

Still, I was an avid player since everything else ran decently well, until I was forced off of windows to linux. Linux performance is absurdly bad. For some inexplicable reason, there's no linux version, so you're forced to run it with Proton. Whoever says this game runs fine in Proton is lying to you. 99% of Proton versions crash on startup, and frame rates are below 1fps at all times. There are no settings to increase performance to any noticeable degree, and if there are mods to make it run faster, I don't know about them. I really, really miss this game.

147710902.review:
I have to be really honest, I absolutely love this game to death. 

This game is fantastic for me, I love the concept and I love the gameplay. it's just perfect. While I haven't seen the whole story, I'm loving it so far. 
Some of the main points I love about it: 
- The combat is PERFECT, and I love only having one weapon/power to use at a time (also the same sort of thing with relics too).
- I love the faith system, it works so well. Not only are they effected by things like starvation and just general unpleasantness, but they're affected by the rituals you choose and if you say no to a follower request.
- The fleeces (the cloak/cape things) not only look amazing but give you PERKS. 
- I've been loving the boss fights. I play on medium and they're CHALLENGING, but the fact you just return to your camp (HQ) and you can upgrade your crown or work on upgrading is perfect. 
I'm not too bad at combat, but I've beaten two of the four bosses so far. I'm halfway to the third one and I'm obsessed with this game. 

Something that needs mentioning:
The doctrines. One of my absolute all time favourite things in this game is the AMOUNT of doctrines there are. There are so many different ways you could take your cult. It's just amazing, you could be ruthless and cold-hearted or be more lenient and heart-warming. It's completely your choice which makes this game SO replay-able. There's so many options to make each playthrough different than the last.

147653208.review:
The Cult of Lamb is a fun, replayable and aesthetically appealing game about making and looking after a cult of inept followers. The main challenge of the game is balancing growing your cult and beating the bosses, since if you go on an adventure for too long your citizens get angry and hungry. While at times this can be annoying, most of the time it's just a quick fix that is kinda like doing a daily chore. It's interesting watching the cult go from a inept to self sufficient

The controls are smooth and everything from the dashing to the combos attacks, the weapon system is simple yet effective in it's execution, making the player choose whether they want a fast weapon with low damage or a slow weapon with high damage was a good decision. It might have been better to give players the choice of a weapon before spawning in and not having it be RNG but it isn't a big issue.

The side missions are a bit of a let down in terms of fun factor. The first three you encounter in the game is 

The juxtaposition between the cutesy art style and the blood and monsters in the game make for a nicely unique experience. It's hard to say that a games art style is unique in this day and age (Exceptions being Cuphead and Faith: The Unholy Trilogy) but this games art style might just qualify as a unique style as it's imagery is both disturbingly detailed and simplistic at the same time.

This is easily one of the best indie games to come out of 2020s and it is worth the price. Additionally their response to the Unity controversy was well done and not in poor taste like other indie teams. 8/10

147375033.review:
Without a doubt one of the most fun games I have ever played.
The combination of roguelike dungeon crawler + colony management makes for one of the most satisfying gameplay loops I have ever played.
Genuinely, every dungeon run has me more excited to build up my cult, and building my cult has me excited to go back into the dungeon.
Having 100%'d the game, including post-update - the pacing of the end-game and post-game is excellent. If you REALLY love cult of the lamb, you can easily sink hours and hours into the game.
It's one of the most polished games - ever. The art, music, UX, and systems in the game are unbelievably polished, and that absolutely does not go unnoticed. 
The only "issue" I have is that the game feels too easy, but there's a lot you can do in game to mitigate that and make it feel at least decently challenging. Regardless, it's a lot of fun.
Cannot recommend this game more.

This game is great at everything! Graphics, variety, gameplay, soundtrack, possibilities/options, EVERYTHING.
It manages to give you a lot of possible things to do, without making you feel overwhelmed, which takes some fine crafting, if you ask me. You get to choose how to run your cult, not only you define what type of cult will it be, but how will you decorate it, how your followers will be named and will they look like. You have great variety when it's time to fight, because there are some great mechanics around battle: no world exploration is the same ever, since the map and your fighting options will be randomized each time. It's a very well achieved game, with the perfect balance between cute and dark, with great characters and dialogues. I 100% recommend playing this game.

The game forces you to maintain the base to unlock further levels to play. It’s the mandatory thing in this game and it comes with an extremely terrible design. Even at the highest base level there are a ton of things that players still need to do manually. You can assign a follower to do the cooking but you still need to order each dish manually every day. You can let them do the farm thing but you still have input seed, collect fertilizer and put those fertilizer in a box manually.

There is a ton of work in the base but there is no work management system. You can’t check which work is not assigned. And the worker in this game is a follower which can get older and stop working. But don’t worry there is no management system that tells you about this, you just need to remember it all by yourself.

The time loop in the game passes quite fast which is really bad, it keeps you in a terrible loop so quick. By doing the base management thing it took more than half of the day in the game. It’s much better if time gets slower and every task in the base has its limitations.

It’s a cult game that I really want to have 0 followers, stop everything about the base management and focus only on adventure. But the game does not allow it to because without base and follower you can’t go further in this game. Don’t get scammed by screenshot of this game where it has a lot of combat scenes, those are 20% scenes you found in the game where 80% is do your cult thing.

147046823.review:
I had a really great time with Cult of the Lamb! From the farm-sim style cult management to the roguelite dungeon crawling to the demonic visual theming of the whole game, it was a blast.

I found the difficulty maybe a bit on the easy side, save for the third major boss, who kicked my ass real bad for some reason. But the combat kept me on my toes enough for me to never get bored of it. The dungeon crawling aspect was very fun, though I kept getting stuck with the claw weapons for my runs, which I really hated using because I wasn't a fan of the three-hit combo they did. It's random chance which weapon type you get and I'm pretty sure I didn't so much as see a sword for the last two main areas of the game. It was all claws, daggers, and hammers for me. Just bad luck I guess. Loved the daggers and hammers though.

Another thing I loved was the game's aesthetic, which makes sense given I'm a big Binding of Isaac fan I guess. It just oozes personality and everything looks so crisp and vibrant. Pretty much everything you do in the game is also accompanied by very satisfying sound design and fun animations that just make interacting with the world and your cultists feel worthwhile, even if only for the sheer enjoyment of it.

I think my one complaint (if I had to have one) would be that I felt like things started to drag a bit near the end for me, as upgrades began to feel superfluous and not really worth getting outside of checking off a box on my list, but I'm willing to chalk that up to me being too slow to grow my cult's size early on. I'd bet the progression feels a lot smoother when you focus the dungeon stuff a bit more heavily than I did.

Again, this is a really fantastic game and I can't wait to see what the team behind it does next!

146900202.review:
Great first introduction to roguelikes and satanism! :D

Cult of The Lamb is a mix between a Stardew Valley-esque resource management game and a dungeon delving roguelike. Both sides of the game are solid and support each other well, but aren't particularly deep. That's not bad, it's very fun and smooth and has a good sense of metaprogression, but if you're looking for a hardcore roguelike, this isn't it.

The aesthetic of this game manages to stay consistent in how adorably horrifying it is. It appears cute at first glance, but then you notice the screaming faces trapped inside the mushrooms in the background, crying blood! :D

On the resource management side, you're tending to the needs of your followers. You can cook for them, clean after them, do little sidequests for them, watch them grow old and make meals out of them, and condemn them to several different fates worse than death! Fun! :D

In terms of getting 100%, it's relatively easy if you get good at it. It is, however, the most evil platinum I've ever gotten. At several points was I clutching my Steam Deck, crying "It's for the achievement!" while committing the most devilish acts. But that sweet ding of a 1,2% achievement makes it all worth it! :D

146684135.review:
Cult of the Lamb is a casual game with little depth, which appears to be its intent. This does not make it a bad game, but rather, a good one for its audience.

If you've ever found yourself interested in the Roguelike genre but unable to dedicate time or mental energy to popular staples, Cult of the Lamb is great. The same is true for colony simulators. It touches on the very basics of each genre in a way where you can safely play with them as a casual player, which is a great thing, as both genres are typically rather intensive.

The game is not very deep. You learn how it works and that's it. The things that change in the mechanics don't actually change them much, making it very easy to cruise. As a game intended for casual play, this makes perfect sense. At the same time, there is space to make your own challenges and create your own difficulty. You simply have to make that choice yourself.

That's not to say it'll be as fun for non-casuals. Optomizing is easy, combat rather dull due to the roguelike elements not really mattering and runs needing to be short to account for the colony management, and as many elements can't be changed to make things harder or more interesting as those that can. (Many being staples, such as locking yourself into a specific weapon, not upgrading your skills, etc.)

All in all, it's not a great game, but it is a good one. It's made for a specific audience and caters to that audience well, but it lacks pull for those outside of it. If you're looking for a casual experience, Cult of the Lamb is a great choice. As a lover of roguelikes and colony sims myself, it's actually refreshing to have something to play even when I can't give it my all.

Now I'll just come out of the gate and say it like it is, is this game hard? No not really, at least compared to most other roguelites this game is fairly forgiving and on the easy side. Is this game even a roguelite? Yes but I feel like the main appeal is the base building moreso than combat, as the split seems at least 50/50 between the two gameplay loops.

However this is not at all to say I disliked the game, in fact it was very enjoyable. While it can be very easy to breeze through the game if you are experienced in other roguelite/bullet hell games while taking few deaths or hits, it is still a very enjoyable game for someone like me, who tends to get bored of base builder games and I even found myself wishing I had a bigger base to build more stuff. Case in point being that if you are a fan of the roguelite or builder genre then I recommend you pick this game up, not only is it cute but the gameplay isn't too bad and even if you're a hardcore roguelite expert you might still enjoy the time you spend on this game.

146632971.review:
A roguelike and city builder in one,
Cult of the Lamb is a great looking game! Having a cute art style that makes it okay to have unorthodox Cult and demonic themes, from sacrificing your flock, to making them eat poop.
The soundtrack slaps! Great tunes that i never got sick of even after hours of playing.

The combat is simple but tight, a light attack, heavy attack (I got it later in the game), special ability and a satisfying dodge, complemented with a good amount of weapons and ability variation. Unlock Talons to give different buffs and perks to help you on your way. Runs generally last 10-15 minutes with a boss fight at the end.

The base building / City building aspect of the game had a surprising amount of depth, from humble beginnings doing a lot of the mundane tasks of cleaning and cooking for your cult, late game having a fully self running system of followers. A massive amount of decorative buildings and paths to let your creativity run wild.
Levelling  up your character you use the temple, performing Sermons Rituals and Doctrines to shape how your cult will work was enjoyable at the start but got a bit grindy and boring having to do the same rituals and Sermons on repeat to level up at the end of the game.

Aside from the dungeon crawling and city building there are a few side quest and mini areas you can travel for extra content and a enjoyable dice minigame called Knucklebones that i found myself playing for a while to be honest.

Overall, a enjoyable game that is worth 10-15 hours of your time
Yes i recommend to give this one a go.

A classic arcade dungeon-crawler and farm/community sim with a twist. They blend surreal horror and gore with absolute wholesomeness. Even though it always recommends controller, it plays just fine on keyboard with a tweak or two- and had adaptive modes ranging from casual to permanent-death. So its inclusive to that extent, but also has LGBT and gender-queer/non-binary characters which makes me so happy. Every assent of the game is so fun and well-paced and balanced. One moment I'm wrecking s*** in the beautifully illustrated combat areas, the next makes me almost cry when a scrap of lore pieces together a bittersweet tale. I love this game SO much, and I didn't expect a free DLC that's basically its own sequel! I really can't think of any complaint- other than I hate the enemies with shields! >0<
